title: Comparatives & Superlatives (Advanced)
description: Master advanced comparison structures including 'as...as', 'less...than', and double comparatives.

rules.title: As...As (Equal Comparison)
rules.explanation: Use 'as + adjective/adverb + as' to show two things are equal. Use 'not as...as' when they are not equal.

examples.sentence: Solar energy is as important as wind energy.
Electric cars are not as cheap as regular cars yet.
examples.translation: 전기차는 아직 일반 차만큼 싸지 않아요.

examples.sentence: This forest is as old as the one in the national park.
examples.translation: 이 숲은 국립공원에 있는 숲만큼 오래됐어요.

rules.title: Less...Than (Inferior Comparison)
rules.explanation: Use 'less + adjective + than' to show something has a smaller degree of a quality.

examples.sentence: Bicycles are less harmful to the environment than cars.
This solution is less expensive than the alternative.
Renewable energy is less polluting than fossil fuels.
examples.translation: 재생 에너지는 화석 연료보다 덜 오염시켜요.

rules.title: The + Comparative, The + Comparative
rules.explanation: Use this structure to show that two changes happen together. As one thing changes, the other changes too.

examples.sentence: The more we recycle, the less waste we produce.
examples.translation: 우리가 더 많이 재활용할수록 쓰레기를 덜 만들어요.

examples.sentence: The warmer the climate gets, the more ice melts.
examples.translation: 기후가 따뜻해질수록 더 많은 얼음이 녹아요.

examples.sentence: The faster we act, the better the results will be.
examples.translation: 우리가 빨리 행동할수록 결과가 더 좋을 거예요.

rules.title: Much/Far/Even + Comparative
rules.explanation: Use 'much', 'far', 'even', 'a lot', or 'a bit' before comparatives to show degree.

examples.sentence: Climate change is much more serious than people think.
examples.translation: 기후 변화는 사람들이 생각하는 것보다 훨씬 심각해요.

examples.sentence: Pollution levels are far higher in cities.
examples.translation: 오염 수준은 도시에서 훨씬 더 높아요.

examples.sentence: This year's drought is even worse than last year's.

rules.title: One of the + Superlative + Plural Noun
rules.explanation: Use this structure to single out something as being among the top or bottom of a group.
rules.structure: one of the + superlative + plural noun

examples.sentence: The Amazon is one of the most important ecosystems on Earth.
examples.translation: 아마존은 지구에서 가장 중요한 생태계 중 하나예요.

examples.sentence: Plastic pollution is one of the biggest environmental problems.
examples.translation: 플라스틱 오염은 가장 큰 환경 문제 중 하나예요.

examples.sentence: Tigers are one of the most endangered species in the world.
examples.translation: 호랑이는 세계에서 가장 멸종 위기에 처한 종 중 하나예요.

rules.title: Comparative + and + Comparative
rules.explanation: Use this structure to show something is continuously increasing or decreasing.

examples.sentence: The weather is getting hotter and hotter each year.
examples.translation: 날씨가 매년 점점 더 더워지고 있어요.

examples.sentence: More and more people are choosing eco-friendly products.
examples.translation: 점점 더 많은 사람들이 친환경 제품을 선택하고 있어요.

examples.sentence: Water resources are becoming scarcer and scarcer.

exercises.question: The more we recycle, _____ waste we produce.
Electric cars are not _____ cheap _____ gas cars.
Climate change is _____ serious than many people realize.
Bicycles are _____ harmful to the environment than cars.
The Amazon is one of _____ ecosystems on Earth.
The weather is getting hotter _____ hotter.
This year's storm was _____ worse than last year's.

exercises.original: If we act faster, the results will be better.
exercises.answer: The faster we act, the better the results will be.

exercises.question: _____ and more people are using public transport.
Pollution levels in cities are _____ higher than in rural areas.
